clinical_study.brief_title: Dietary Intervention Replacing Carbohydrate With Protein and Fat Has Greater Effect on Peripheral Blood Mononuclear Cell Metabolites Than on Plasma Metabolites in Patients With Prediabetes or Type-2 Diabetes
clinical_study.official_title: Dietary Intervention Replacing Carbohydrate With Protein and Fat Has Greater Effect on Peripheral Blood Mononuclear Cell Metabolites Than on Plasma Metabolites in Patients With Prediabetes or Type-2 Diabetes

brief_summary.textblock: This study examined whether dietary-induced reductions in lipoprotein-associated phospholipase A2 (Lp-PLA2) activity in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) and plasma affected metabolic profiles in PBMCs and plasma.

detailed_description.textblock: Eighty nonobese patients (aged 40-70 years) with prediabetes or newly diagnosed type-2 diabetes were randomly assigned to a control group (normal diet with refined rice) or a whole-grain group (replacement of refined rice with whole-grains and legumes). This dietary intervention replaced approximately 7% of carbohydrate-derived energy with approximately 4% of protein-derived energy and approximately 3% of fat-derived energy.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from baseline in Lp-PLA2 at 12 weeks
Change from baseline in Lp-PLA2 at 12 weeks

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Change in L-leucine, oleamide, lysoPC (16:0), and lysoPC (18:0)

other_outcome.time_frame: Changes from baseline in LDL particle size at 12 weeks

intervention.description: Subjects in the control group maintained the usual refined-rice diet.

Subjects in the whole-grain group replaced refined rice with a mix of 1/3 legumes, 1/3 barley, and 1/3 wild rice three times per day, and increased vegetable intake to at least 6 units (30-70 g/unit) per day for sufficient dietary fiber intake.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- subjects who had IFG (100≤ fasting glucose <126 mg/dL)
- or newly diagnosed type-2 diabetes (fasting glucose ≥126 mg/dL)
Exclusion Criteria:
- current and/or past history of cardiovascular disease including angina
- liver or kidney dysfunction
- thyroid or pituitary disease
- pregnancy or lactation
- taking medications or supplements
